greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest k such that (bigomega(k) - 1) * omega(k) = n, and 0 if none exists, where omega = A001221, bigomega = A001222.
comment: For n > 0, a(n) is of the form 2^k*primorial(d) where d is a divisor of n and k = n / d - d + 1.  a(n) is never 0 since A307409(2^(n+1)) = n. - _Andrew Howroyd_, Nov 04 2019
link: Andrew Howroyd, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
example: The sequence of terms together with their prime signatures begins:
program: (PARI) a(n)={if(n<1, 1, my(m=oo); fordiv(n, d, if(d<=n/d+1, m=min(m, 2^(n/d-d+1)*vecprod(primes(d))))); m)} \\ _Andrew Howroyd_, Nov 04 2019
xref: Positions of first appearances in A307409.
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Nov 02 2019
ext: Terms a(23) and beyond from _Andrew Howroyd_, Nov 03 2019
